2009/11/30 Ken <kstanley@...>
>
[...]
>
> I was surprised of course by how far it got. Shimon has pointed out that maybe some other neuroevolution approach or even
> some other machine learning approach could also have done well (although Fermilab did try several approaches that did not fare > as well as NEAT at the time). In a sense it may be luck for NEAT that NEAT happened to be what was on hand. However, in any
> case, it is to NEAT's credit that it was indeed the approach used for this accomplishment.


Yes, potentially something like GP say would be just as good but there
are potentially a few things in NEAT that come together to make it the
best choice currently. I'm thinking of the fact it evolves recursive
networks and also the speciation and fitness sharing. I think there
are GP variants with these and perhaps a variant with all of the
above, but I don't think the ideas are central to GP. Hence an attempt
at using 'GP' might fail because it depends on understanding those
differences and selecting the appropriate code base. With NEAT however
these ideas have been central to the methodology from the outset, thus
all of the various code bases and papers tend to implement *all* of
these ideas and are generally more consistent - it doesn't matter so
much which one you pick.

I might be wrong but it's possible. I still think that GP and NEAT
really sit within a spectrum of network/function evolution approaches.

Colin.
